sn24.70:3.1: 70 The Self Is Neither Happy Nor Suffering
sn24.70:4.2: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what and insisting on what, does the view arise:
sn24.70:4.3: “‘The self is neither happy nor suffering, and is sound after death’?”
sn24.70:4.4: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. …”
sn24.70:5.1: “When form exists, because of grasping form and insisting on form, the view arises:
sn24.70:5.2: ‘The self is neither happy nor suffering, and is sound after death.’
sn24.70:5.6: consciousness exists, because of grasping consciousness and insisting on consciousness, the view arises:
sn24.70:5.7: ‘The self is neither happy nor suffering, and is sound after death.’
sn24.70:6.1: What do you think, mendicants? Is form permanent or impermanent?”
sn24.70:6.7: When this exists, grasping at this, the view arises:
sn24.70:6.8: ‘The self is neither happy nor suffering, and is sound after death.’
sn24.70:6.18: When this exists, grasping at this, the view arises:
sn24.70:6.19: ‘The self is neither happy nor suffering, and is sound after death.’”
